https://t.co/zEs0jnF1DM https://t.co/HtSOnRn7A5 “The stickers I designed show an uplifting point of view of what Juneteenth means to me. I wanted to portray the loving aspect of Juneteenth through the embrace of two people who have love for each other and are building each other up.” –Marco Cheatham https://t.co/wGdEZwHZM5 “When designing these, I wanted to focus on the sensory aspect of shackles and chains. The chains are breaking into confetti for that celebration aspect, and the stars reflect life – a spinoff of patriotism and the magic that comes from breaking those chains.”  –Mina Elise https://t.co/NjElYx9NA7 Here’s the story behind their inspiration, in their own words. 

 “I was drawn to the concepts of joy and solidarity. I feel it’s really important to show how we connect with one another and how together we can heal through these traumatic experiences.”  –Andrea Pippins https://t.co/5ZJuXVnISz We commissioned three Black artists – Andrea Pippins, Mina Elise and Marco Cheatham – to create stickers that honor what Juneteenth means to them.

This #SaferInternetDay, we’ve brought together cyberbullying and child protection experts and t… We want to create a safe and supportive community for everyone on Instagram. For even more tips, visit: https://t.co/Vgco7yma5R To give you more control over who can contact you on Instagram, there’s a new way to limit who can send you direct messages. The feature lets only the people you follow message you and add you to group threads. https://t.co/UyhOpcCAZG We also want to help stop bullying before it happens. If someone writes a potentially offensive comment or caption, they’ll get a prompt saying it’s similar to content that’s been reported for bullying. We’ve found this can encourage people to reconsider what they’re posting. ICYMI, we’ve also been rolling out more features to help prevent bullying. When you restrict an account, only they can see their comments on your posts. And they can’t see when you’ve read their direct messages or when you’re active on Instagram. https://t.co/dOBhxFAITO If your account’s been disabled, there’s a new way to appeal in the app. When you try to log in, you’ll see an option to “Request a Review.” Tap it and we’ll review your disabled account and potentially restore it. We'll roll out these features over the coming weeks. https://t.co/W9r6B7dpau You can also tap “More Options” for suggested actions – like muting, blocking or unfollowing accounts you’ve reported. And if you disagree with our decision on the content, you can request a review and we’ll take a second look. Now when you report something that shouldn’t be on Instagram (like bullying or offensive content), you can get updates through Support Requests. It’s a new feature in the app that shows you the status of your reports. Go to “Settings”  –> “Support Requests.” https://t.co/6hag2ccKtx For #SaferInternetDay, we’re sharing some tips on how to stay safe on Instagram and take more control over your experience❤️ Right now on our story: we're looking at #Oscars night in Instagram hashtags.
